intro: Deyeuxia rupestris f. pilosa, commonly known as the hairy rock sedge, is a perennial grass species native to certain regions of Asia. It is characterized by its dense, tufted growth habit and hairy foliage, which gives it its specific epithet "pilosa." The plant typically grows in rocky or disturbed soils, often in open, sunny habitats. Its inflorescence consists of a cylindrical spikelet, typical of the Cyperaceae family. It plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native environment and is of interest to botanists and ecologists.
